awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: DeepEdge: QoE-based Resource Allocation for Future Heterogeneous and Dynamic Edge-IoT Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The emerging Internet of Things (IoT) is connecting increasing numbers of smart devices and enabling varieties of heterogeneous IoT applications, empowered by cloud and edge computing technologies. In particular, edge or fog computing technologies will significantly benefit IoT applications that are delay-sensitive, bandwidth/data intensive, or that require closer intelligence. However, for effective Edge-IoT resource allocation, significant challenges exist due to the following requirements and constraints: 1) the demand side that a massive number of IoT devices can run heterogeneous applications with various Quality of Service (QoS) requirements and different priorities; and 2) the supply side that the edge clouds need to dynamically and optimally allocate limited and multidimensional resources (CPU, storage, and bandwidth) at geospatially distributed points. The objective of this project is to respond to these challenges by designing and developing a new Edge-IoT framework named DeepEdge using deep online learning that allocates resources to heterogeneous IoT applications and dynamic IoT devices to maximize users' Quality of Experience (QoE). The proposed research will advance knowledge and fundamentally change the way future edge computing systems work in supporting heterogeneous and dynamic IoT applications. The transformative research outcomes will benefit users and society with inexpensive and effective IoT application delivery, and contribute to important societal challenges in supporting emerging IoT devices and applications. The project will also broadly involve and impact K-12 underrepresented groups and female students in computer science, and develop strong research and education integration for various levels of students. 

The goal of the proposed research is to develop the framework, model, and algorithms in effectively delivering heterogeneous IoT applications on edge clouds and provisioning high-quality QoE for users. More specifically, the project will result in: i) a new QoE model to quantify the users satisfaction and its related factors including multiple applications QoS requirements and applications priority; ii) a new deep machine learning based two-stage resource allocation scheme that will adapt application QoS requirements according to available resources at the edge cloud and maintain application's priority, and will intelligently and jointly allocate communication and computation resources with the objective of maximization of users QoE; iii) a novel deep Q-learning scheme that will dynamically select the most appropriate edge nodes to handle the multiple application tasks with the goal to optimize the task execution delay; iv) a hardware and software test-bed implementation to validate and evaluate the effectiveness, efficiency, and the practicality of the proposed research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A) Intellectual merit outcomes. The project led to a series of new architectures and designs of the future Edge-IoT systems, with corresponding implementation and validation.

The first research outcome is the novel Edge-IoT framework named DeepEdge using deep online learning to allocate resources to heterogeneous IoT applications and dynamic IoT devices to achieve optimal users’ Quality of Experience (QoE). The DeepEdge framework includes an Edge-IoT resource allocation model, a two-stage online Q-learning scheme, and the practical implementation and comprehensive numerical analysis and evaluation. The new architecture and designs together achieve optimal allocation of multi-type edge resources and best user experiences among competing heterogeneous IoT applications.

The second research outcome is the novel data-driven Behavior-aware Intelligent and Fair Resource Management paradigm named BEHAVE. We developed the BEHAVE framework to intelligently and fairly allocate edge resources to heterogeneous IoT devices with consideration of their behavior of resource demand (BRD). BEHAVE holistically addresses the management technical barriers by: 1) building an efficient scheme for modeling and assessment of the BRD of IoT devices based on their resource requests and resource usage; 2) expanding a new Rational, Fair, and Truthful Resource Allocation (RFTA) model that binds the devices’ BRD and resource allocation to achieve fair allocation and encourage truthfulness in resource demand; and 3) developing an enhanced deep reinforcement learning (EDRL) scheme to achieve the RFTA goals.

The third research outcome is the novel I-HARF architecture for hierarchical resource facilitation. We develop I-HARF to adapt to dynamic Edge-IoT situations including outlandish situations, mobility, application’s sensitivity, and varying resource demands of IoT applications based on time and location. I-HARF achieves adaptive facilitation and holistically addresses the facilitation technical barriers by: 1) adopting hierarchical structure which efficiently migrates the resource facilitation from intra-zone to inter-zone levels; 2) extending novel intra-zone and inter-zone optimization models to boost the utilities of the edge servers and the IoT applications; and 3) developing a novel DRL designs that intelligently facilitate the edge resources in both intra-zone and inter-zone respectively.

The fourth research outcome is the design and implementation of the novel framework to enable proactive resiliency and offer controllable and graceful application degradation during workload stress or disruptions for future Edge-IoT systems. We propose a two-level REPA framework and functional modules. It includes the lower-level zone edge administrators (ZEAs) and the upper-level institution edge administrator (IEA). The two levels coordinate and jointly optimize the intra-zone and inter-zone resource allocation to achieve both resiliency and application graceful degradation goals.

 

B) Broader impacts outcomes. The project led to a series of broad impacts activities and outcomes as follows.

The first outcome is the support of K-12 underrepresented high school students via the CLIMB (Collaborative Laboratory Internships and Mentoring Blueprint) program that is focused on providing paid summer research internship to disadvantaged students from north St. Louis (both Jennings and University City school districts). The project supported one minority student researcher position each year for 6-week paid internships, the students work 32 hours per week over 4 days in a research experience of their choice, and then assemble on the fifth day of each week to discuss career strategies and interview guests about their career pathways.

The second outcome is the support of new course development. We incorporated the team based learning and the Bloom’s Taxonomy methods in designing and developing a new course IoT System and Security at both graduate and undergraduate levels at UMSL. The course became one of the core courses of the cybersecurity undergraduate and graduate degree programs. The course provided students the opportunities to understand the key rationale of intelligent Edge-IoT systems and security, and develop, demonstrate, and evaluate new security applications. We leveraged application demonstration, hands-on group project, and evaluation process to enhance the students’ learning experience.

The third outcome is the support of post-doctoral scholar and Ph.D. students. The project supported one post-doctoral scholar during the whole project period. The PI provided research training, guidance, and professional development in preparing for the future career. Additional training on grant proposals writing, publications and presentations were also provided. The project supported two Ph.D. students at both GMU and UMSL. This project provided a series of opportunities that get the them involved in related research tasks and activities. We also encouraged them to develop skills in teaching, learning, mentoring and leadership through GMU’s training and outreach activities.

The fourth outcome is the support of female college students via the “Women.can” club activities. The project provided training and career development guidance opportunities to the club members. The project provided annual workshops on “women in CS and cybersecurity” to guide their research and career development.
